contentData.text:
Faith, hope and love.

We can't live without them. But we all need to grow in them. These groups help.
Ever wonder if there’s something more? Unsure what you believe? Is Christianity confusing to you?

At St Philemon’s we make it easy for people to ask questions: big ones, doubting ones, hostile ones. You can do that with someone from church meeting up with you anytime that suits you. Or you can do it in a group with others who are also exploring. Many people have found them helpful in getting clearer on what they believe.

 

Here is information about the current course:
Why should I care for my soul?

contentData.title: - Your soul is the most precious part of you. It lasts forever.
contentData.text:
Jesus said: ‘What good is it for someone to gain the whole world, yet forfeit their soul? Or what can anyone give in exchange for their soul?’ (Mark 8:36-37)

Read the whole chapter.

contentData.title: - If your soul is healthy and rested, you can endure almost anything. If itâ€™s in bad shape, you will often be tired, scared, anxious, crushed.
contentData.text:
‘The human spirit can endure in sickness, but a crushed spirit who can bear?’ (Proverbs 18:14)

Video of Joni's story

contentData.title: - Anyone who lets Jesus lead them will find true soul-rest.
contentData.text:
Jesus said: 'Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light. (Matthew 11:28-30)

Song about soul-rest with Jesus
Here are a few different ways to care for your soul:

The idea of reading the Bible may seem daunting. We suggest you start with a small section, perhaps one of the four gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke or John).

You can find them online to read or listen to. Get in touch if you want a free physical copy.

We often suggest just the first chapter of John’s gospel. We have a great booklet with helpful notes to guide you through.

contentData.title: Read more
contentData.text:
We’d recommend reading it through with a Christian who can help answer any questions you may have.

 

- Already have a Christian friend? Ask them to read through the John Chapter One booklet with you.

 

- Want to be linked to a Christian? Fill in this form and we will link you with a Christian who can read through John Chapter One with you.

Actually, all of us are working out what we believe!

We frequently host groups that make it easy for people to ask questions: big ones, doubting ones, hostile ones. No-one gets put on the spot. Tell us what time in the week suits you and we’ll send you information about groups that happen then.

You don’t need to believe anything in particular to come. Our services are a great way to find out more about Jesus and to consider what trust in him would look like.

You can find out all about them here.
We'd love to! God really listens to prayer - we've seen it again and again. Get in touch and let us know what we can pray for you.

Many people have only picked up vague impressions from here and there but Christianity has never been explained to them.

Here’s a very short summary.

We'd happily buy you a book if you'd like a longer read. Get in contact with your address and we'll send you one.

At St Philemon’s we make it easy for people to ask questions: big ones, doubting ones, hostile ones. You can do that with someone from church meeting up with you anytime that suits you. Or you can do it in a group with others who are also exploring. All of that is online at the moment.

 

If you’re interested in either a group or individual (online) meet up, email info@stphilemons.co.uk.

Our groups are more than just Bible studies: they include prayer, encouragement, sharing what God is doing in our lives, accountability, and working together in the mission of telling others about Jesus.

contentData.title: What are Life Groups?
contentData.text:
Life Groups are small communities of 6-12 people meeting on Zoom during the week. We have men’s, women’s and mixed groups.

 

These groups are the primary place where the gospel is applied to real life issues. They are at the heart of St Philemon’s pastoral care. Each group is led by trained leaders, who themselves receive continued support and oversight.

 

Each group meets with the expectation that Jesus speaks through the Bible to transform and renew lives.

contentData.title: What are Life Groups?
contentData.text:
Life Groups are communities of 6-12 people meeting most weeks in homes and locations around Toxteth, and more recently on Zoom. 

 

Life Groups are about friendships that help us follow Jesus. When we meet, Jesus speaks through the Bible to help us. But our groups are much more than Bible studies. They're places where we connect the good news of Jesus to each other's lives and put that gospel into practice together. That makes them ideal both for people already following Jesus and for people who want to know what following Jesus would mean for them.

 

Each group has its own personality – shaped by its members – but all have trained leaders who receive ongoing support and oversight. Therefore these groups are at the heart of our church’s pastoral care.Life Groups are small communities of 6-12 people meeting in homes in Toxteth during the week. We have men’s, women’s and mixed groups.

 

These groups are the primary place where the gospel is applied to real life issues. They are at the heart of St Philemon’s pastoral care. Each group is led by trained leaders, who themselves receive continued support and oversight.

 

Each group meets with the expectation that Jesus speaks through the Bible to transform and renew lives.

contentData.title: Why are Life Groups important?
contentData.text:
A PLACE TO APPLY THE GOSPEL TO OUR LIVES

We need others to help us apply the truth about the gospel to our daily lives. The implications of our life with Christ are broad – so broad that we rarely understand them by ourselves. As we remind one another about grace, we help each other open our lives to transformation according to God’s purposes.

 

A PLACE FOR CARING FOR EACH OTHER

The Bible tells us to ‘encourage, serve, rejoice, weep with, correct, instruct, sing to, build up, accept, and love one another.’ These commands are best followed in personal relationships. Life Groups also serve to keep St Philemon’s leaders aware of pastoral concerns or troubles facing members of the church family.

 

A PLACE TO GROW

Life Groups are a place where spiritual gifts are discerned and developed. Members are encouraged not merely to attend or ‘consume’, but to invest themselves in relationships with other members, actively looking to support one another in a variety of ways.

contentData.title: How much commitment does a Life Group require?
contentData.text:
Life Groups work best when we get stuck in. That's when they become places with friendships that really do help us follow Jesus. Regular attendance helps, so come as consistently as you can. If you have to miss a week, don’t worry, but think how you can follow up with others in the group that week.

 

You are welcome to try out a group a few times before committing to it. If you would like to find out more, email info@stphilemons.co.uk or contact Andrew or any Group leader you know.

Looking after children brings particular joys and challenges, and we want to care for you in them. We believe we do this best by supporting you in your relationship with Jesus.  

 

We try to provide opportunities for you to listen to God's Word without the distraction of children. We also give chances to meet with others to discuss the Bible, share burdens, pray, and to reach out to our community. Find out more: Crèche and Mini Phillies; Daytime Life Group.

Looking after children brings particular joys and challenges, especially at the moment with no playgroups running. We want to care for you in them.

 

Find out more: Mini Phillies.

The Sunday Topic is a weekly online discussion where we can think things through together as a church family.

We look at a different topic each week – feel free to join for whichever ones interest you.

 

Our next topic: Philly's Sports Players Meet-Up.

Meet with other sports players to pray for each other and help each other play and speak for Jesus.

Central Prayer Meeting

 

We depend on our Father in heaven for everything.

 

Each month our church gets together on Zoom, every group and language, for a time of prayer. These meetings are real highlights as we gather around God’s word, hear news about what’s going on, get the latest from local and global partners we have as a church, and respond to it all in prayer.

 

We normally meet on the first Thursday of the month (7.30pm).

We depend on our Father in heaven for everything.

 

Each month our church gets together, every group and language, for a time of prayer. These meetings are real highlights as we gather around God’s word, hear news about what’s going on, get the latest from local and global partners we have as a church, and respond to it all in prayer.

 

We normally meet on the first Thursday of the month (7.30pm).
We repeat the meeting on the following Monday (2pm) for those of us who struggle to make it in the evening.

Morning Prayer Meetings

We meet in the church building every weekday morning at 8.45am, read a portion of the Bible together and then pray.
